content: The "Urban Jobs Act of 2011" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings and purpose. Congress finds that one-third of minority youth are unemployed, the labor force participation rate for persons without a high school diploma is significantly lower, African-American and Hispanic students have a lower graduation rate, and high school dropouts from the class of 2004 will cost the nation over $325 billion in lost wages, taxes, and productivity. High school dropouts have a 55 percent or lower chance of graduating, costing the nation over $325 billion in lost wages, taxes, and productivity. Only 52 percent of students in the 50 largest cities graduate from high school, falling below the national average of 70 percent. Urban districts have an average graduation rate of 60 percent. The national high school graduation rate is 70 percent, lower than the average of 60 percent for urban districts. High school dropouts earn significantly less over a lifetime compared to graduates. A large percentage of prison inmates have not completed high school. Increasing the high school completion rate by 1 percent for men ages 20 to 60 could save $1.4 billion annually in crime-related costs. Increasing the high school completion rate by 1 percent for men ages 20 to 60 could save $1.4 billion annually in crime-related costs. A 10-percent increase in male high school graduation rate would reduce arrest rates for various crimes. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources to prevent disproportionate youth incarceration. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources for national nonprofit organizations to prevent and reduce disproportionate youth incarceration, especially among minority youth, and to prepare them for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency. SEC. 3. URBAN JOBS PROGRAMS. Amends the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to include a new section on Urban Jobs Programs. The section aims to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for youth aged 18-24 in urban communities, leading them into employment or education for employment. It also focuses on a holistic approach for preparing eligible youth. The application for a grant under the Urban Jobs Program must include a request for the grant amount and proposed uses of funds, as well as how the national intermediary will meet goals for participants such as increased long-term employment, reduced recidivism, and increased attainment. The Secretary of Labor must submit reports detailing the progress of the Urban Jobs Program to Congress annually. The program is exempt from evaluations required under section 172. The Secretary of Labor will establish the National Jobs Council Advisory Committee comprised of 11 members from the private sector. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, known as the Committee, consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary.
